Award.AwardTitle: Young Researcher Participation in Northern Research Forum 2013: Climate Change in Northern Territories
Award.AbstractNarration: This is a small workshop award to support the participation of two early career female scholars in the Northern Research Forum, which will be held in Akureyri, Iceland in the Fall 2013. The Northern Research Forum (NRF) holds an Open Assembly every two years. Each assembly focuses on a different theme of relevance to northerners and northern research. This year?s Assembly theme is Climate Change in Northern Territories: Sharing Experiences and Exploring New Methods, Assessing Socio-Economic Impacts. One of the main objectives of the NRF is to promote the next generation of Arctic researchers by involving emerging scholars in leadership and by selecting a cohort of early career researchers to present their research projects and findings at the Open Assemblies. The aim is to engage early career researchers in dialogue with senior scientists and other professionals and experts as well as representatives of various stakeholder groups and the public. This proposal will support the involvement of two early career scholars from the United States: Dr. Noor Jehan Johnson, a postdoctoral researcher at Brown University, and Amy Wiita, a doctoral candidate at the University of Alaska-Fairbanks. They will join more than 20 other Young Researchers from other Arctic nations, offering an opportunity for exchange of ideas and network building.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the participation of two early career scholars from the United States in the Northern Research Forum (NRF) Assembly held in Akureyri, Iceland, 22 - 23 August 2013. The theme of the Assembly was "Climate Change in Northern Territories." The assembly objective was to address the climate change in Northern territories, sharing experiences, exploring new methods and assessing socio-economic impacts.

Dr. Noor Jehan Johnson, a postdoctoral researcher at Brown University, was selected by conference organizers to serve as a Young Researcher at the Assembly, where she gave a paper entitled "Grantwriting and other translational skills in adaptation practice." The paper drew on research conducted in the Canadian Arctic focusing on how institutions impede or facilitate climate change adaptation. Dr. Johnson also served as a rapporteur for one of the assembly sessions.

Amy Wiita, a doctoral candidate at the University of Alaska-Fairbanks, is a member of the NRF Steering Committee and participated in a Steering Committee meeting at the assembly. Her interdisciplinary research focuses on artists' experience of place and the connections between art and environment, a topic that connected strongly with the assembly theme of climate change.

Because of the international nature of the assembly, participation enabled Dr. Johnson and Ms. Wiita to expand their networks with the Arctic research community in Europe. The Young Researcher program has a particular focus on helping early career scholars build connections with international research networks, and Dr. Johnson participated in a number of special events with other young investigators.
